Description: Terracotta amulet-mould in Nile clay, circular in shape, with impression of a feline head (lion or cat?); remains of yellow paste/glaze inside impression; in red micaceous Nile silt fabric.
Curator's comments: Glazed composition scarabs, scaraboids and amulets produced at Naukratis were usually cast and not carved or incised; this technique, highly characteristic of Naukratite productions, allowed a mass-production of these small objects which were mainly intended for export in the whole Mediterranean area and even as far as Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 177-180, fig. 35). Numerous terracotta moulds for scarabs, scaraboids and amulets were discovered at the site (on the various productions from the Scarab Factory see Webb, forthcoming). Petrie published a similar type to this mould (Petrie 1886, 37, pl. XXXVIII, 12, just profile of the impression published). Gorton, A. F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884-5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for dating, in R. Thomas (ed.), The Naukratis workshop, held at the British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OJ.22) (phase 2)
Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVIII, no. 12) (cast from such mould)
Acquisition name: Donated by: Egypt Exploration Fund (on behalf of)
